Lastly, I would like to return to how the Fourier theory of commutative coherent algebras could be useful towards e.g. the classification of distance-regular graphs.

The commutative coherent algebra is said to be metric (relative to ) if for some ; dually, is said to be cometric (relative to ) if for some .

Suppose is self-dual with Fourier transform on .

By properties of , observe that:

  • If is metric relative to , then for some .
  • Dually, if is cometric relative to , then for some .

So, a self-dual coherent algebra is metric if and only if it is cometric.

It turns out that coherent algebras that are both metric and symmetric can be identified with the adjacency algebras of distance-regular graphs.

Distance-regular graphs whose adjacency algebras are self-dual must then satisfy a number of additional properties and constraints that may be useful towards e.g. classifying them; I will continue to elaborate on this point in future posts.
